summary:
In a splendid display of dominant football, Real Madrid comprehensively outplayed Shakhtar Donetsk in a dynamic encounter at the Santiago Bernabéu Stadium, securing a 4-0 victory. The match showcased Real Madrid's attacking prowess and tactical discipline, leaving Shakhtar struggling to keep pace with their illustrious opponents. Here's an exhaustive account of the game that unraveled on the pitch.

The match commenced with Real Madrid immediately asserting their superiority. From the whistle, there was a clear intent on their part to dominate possession and dictate the tempo. Within moments, the ball went out of play, signaling an early stoppage, but Shakhtar's subsequent throw-in offered little respite as Real Madrid quickly regained control.

Both teams engaged in a series of exchanges that saw the ball go out of play frequently. Shakhtar attempted to build up from the back, but Real Madrid's high pressing game continually applied pressure, forcing turnovers. It didn't take long before the first corner of the match materialized for Real Madrid, although this initial attempt did not trouble Shakhtar's defense as the shot went off target.

Real Madrid continued to pepper Shakhtar’s goal with shots, some on target and others wayward. A meticulously built-up attack saw Karim Benzema take a shot that narrowly missed, illustrating Real Madrid's intent and creating an air of inevitability around their opening goal.

The breakthrough came in the 30th minute following a sequence of persistent Real Madrid attacks. A catastrophic defensive error by Shakhtar allowed Karim Benzema an opportunity he readily capitalized on. Benzema, finding himself with the ball from close range, calmly slotted it into the back of the net to give Real Madrid a 1-0 lead. The goal was a consequence of tenacious pressing and taking advantage of the opposition's mistake.

Soon after, Real Madrid had to make an unexpected substitution due to an injury sustained by Gareth Bale. Rafael Benitez sent Mateo Kovacic onto the pitch in Bale's stead, a forced change but one that didn't disrupt the home side's momentum. Shortly after, tensions began to rise, and Taras Stepanenko received a yellow card for a foul, an incident that underscored the physical nature of the contest.

Real Madrid’s tactical discipline and pressing game continued to fluster Shakhtar, who found it exceedingly difficult to penetrate Real Madrid’s strong defensive setup. By mid-half, Real Madrid's control of the match appeared almost absolute, forcing Shakhtar to revert to long balls and desperate clearances. Luka Modric, Toni Kroos, and Cristiano Ronaldo orchestrated the midfield with aplomb, creating numerous goal-scoring chances.

As the first half neared conclusion, Real Madrid’s attacks became more penetrating and precise. Luka Modric's vision and passing almost resulted in another goal when he set up a teammate, only for the ball to be shot just wide of the post. Cristiano Ronaldo and Karim Benzema had their chances too, further demonstrating Real Madrid's attacking threat.

The first half concluded with Real Madrid firmly in control, both in terms of possession and territorial advantage. Shakhtar managed to hold off further damage but showed little promise in their offensive maneuvers, leaving the pitch with a solitary goal deficit that could have been worse, given Real Madrid's dominant performance.

The second half began with another substitution for Real Madrid, this time with Rafael Benitez bringing on Pepe for Raphael Varane. Shakhtar's kick-off tried to spark some life into their play, but Real Madrid soon set the pace again. Karim Benzema's early cross was quickly intercepted by Shakhtar's defense, setting the tone for another half filled with Real Madrid pressure.

Shakhtar’s efforts to build momentum were consistently thwarted by Real Madrid’s organized pressing and robust midfield. Luka Modric's handball and subsequent fouls led to a series of free-kicks for Shakhtar, but none of these set-pieces troubled the home side's defense. In contrast, Shakhtar's defensive frailties were laid bare early in the half when Taras Stepanenko, already on a yellow card, made a reckless challenge that saw him receive his marching orders with a second yellow, leaving his team a man down and in further peril.

Down to ten men, Shakhtar had an ever-increasing uphill battle. Not long after this incident, a decisive moment arrived in the 50th minute when Shakhtar's Darijo Srna was adjudged to have handled the ball in the box, resulting in a penalty. Cristiano Ronaldo stepped up and powerfully placed his shot into the left side of the goal, doubling Real Madrid's lead to 2-0 in the 54th minute.

The tilt in numerical advantage further emboldened Real Madrid. A relentless battery of attacks was launched, epitomizing their hunt for goals. Isco and Benzema both came close, with efforts narrowly missing the target. Real Madrid’s bench was also vibrant with activity, with Nacho coming on for Sergio Ramos, who couldn't continue due to an injury.

Real Madrid's third goal arrived through another penalty after Marcio Azevedo's handball in the box. Cristiano Ronaldo stepped up once again and coolly converted, adding to his tally and extending Real Madrid's lead to 3-0 in the 65th minute.

Shakhtar, reduced to ten men and three goals down, were unable to mount any significant response. Despite the fresh legs introduced by Shakhtar through substitutions, the pattern of the game remained largely unchanged with Real Madrid maintaining their dominant stance. Shakhtar’s defensive strategy was further compromised by yellow cards and frequent fouls, adding to their woes as the game progressed.

As the clock ticked toward the end, Real Madrid put the finishing touch on an illustrious performance. Cristiano Ronaldo completed his hat-trick in the closing stages, reacting fastest to capitalize on a rebound to head the ball home, clinching a 4-0 victory and further cementing his reputation as one of the world's elite goal-scorers.

The final minutes saw Shakhtar trying to salvage some pride and possibly narrow the goal deficit. However, Real Madrid’s defense, led by Pepe and Marcelo, remained steadfast. Set-piece opportunities for Shakhtar, including a promising cross from Bernard and several corner kicks, fell short as Real Madrid maintained their clean sheet. Keylor Navas, Real Madrid’s goalkeeper, was reliable whenever called upon, making crucial saves and commanding his area effectively.

When the final whistle blew, it confirmed a commanding 4-0 victory for Real Madrid, a well-earned triumph that reflected their superiority on the night. Shakhtar, despite moments of resilience and fight, were thoroughly outmatched. The combination of Real Madrid’s relentless attack, disciplined midfield orchestrations, and solid defense left little room for Shakhtar to maneuver.

In conclusion, Real Madrid's performance was a masterclass in modern football, characterized by rigorous pressing, quick transitions, and clinical finishing. The hattrick hero Cristiano Ronaldo was rightly the star of the show, while Karim Benzema’s opportunistic goal set the tone early. The collective display by Real Madrid underscored their capabilities and sent a resounding message to their competitors.
